conclusion: The problem involves a Stirling cycle for an ideal gas with isothermal and adiabatic processes.
The image shows a P-V diagram of a Stirling cycle with transitions from state A to states B, C, and D.
The number of molecules colliding with a unit area of the wall per unit time depends on the pressure and volume of the gas.
In an isothermal process, the pressure and volume change while the temperature remains constant, meaning n is constant if pV is constant.
In the isothermal process Câ†’D, the pressure at state C must be equal to the pressure at state D, so n is constant.
The change in the number of molecules colliding with the unit area per unit time from state C to state D is 0.
